text: Edouard Silas Edouard Silas (22 August 18278 February 1909) who was born in Amsterdam and died in London, was a Dutch composer and organist. He studied in Paris with Friedrich Kalkbrenner, François Benoist and Jacques Fromental Halévy. He lived in London from 1850. Silas was organist at the Catholic Chapel of Kingston upon Thames and Professor of Harmony at the Guildhall School of Music. He was a composer of symphonies, piano concertos, string quartets and organ works. He composed a Mass for four voices and organ for which he won a Belgian competition for sacred music in 1866 and he also composed other sacred music.Grove's Dictionary of Music and Musicians, 1909. ==Notes== Category:1827 births Category:1909 deaths Category:19th-century male musicians Category:20th-century male musicians Category:Academics of the Guildhall School of Music and Drama Category:Dutch classical composers Category:Dutch classical organists Category:Dutch male classical composers Category:Dutch Romantic composers Category:Male organists Category:Musicians from Amsterdam
title: Edouard Silas
